label: We have written guidelines that prescribe an upper limit on the share of a grant that can be allocated towards core costs. Our guidelines do not allow for any flexibility in the support provided. There are individual(s) amongst the decision makers in our organisation who advocate for making our guidelines more flexible.
name: Core Costs-cc_guidelines-2

desc: The Foreign Contribution Regulation Act (FCRA) limits the amount of foreign funding nonprofits can spend on “administrative” or (non-programme) core costs to 20 percent.
label: We have written guidelines that are flexible and do not prescribe a limit for the share of a grant that can be allocated towards core costs while adhering to relevant regulations. Decision makers in our organisation understand the importance of and are committed to supporting the core cost needs requested by nonprofit partners.
name: Core Costs-cc_guidelines-4

label:
We provide no more than 10% of a total
grant to support core costs.
name: Core Costs-cc_approaches_adopted_01-1

label: We have a fixed range for core cost support between 10% and 15% of the total grant amount. This is based on our organisation’s guidelines and prior experience. We do not consult nonprofit partners to understand their cost structures and needs during the proposal phase.
name: Core Costs-cc_approaches_adopted_01-2

label: We have a fixed range for core cost support between 15% and 20% of the total grant amount. We consult nonprofit partners during the proposal phase to better understand their cost structures and needs.
name: Core Costs-cc_approaches_adopted_01-3

label: There is no room for nonprofit partners to negotiate and advocate for increasing the share of core costs provided.
name: Core Costs-cc_approaches_adopted_02-1

label: There is limited room for select, or a few, partners to negotiate and advocate for increasing the share of core costs provided.
name: Core Costs-cc_approaches_adopted_02-2

label: We are flexible on the core cost support extended to nonprofit partners based on their needs. We support our nonprofit partners and advise them on how best to optimize the pool of core cost support available.
name: Core Costs-cc_approaches_adopted_02-4

label: We do not make an effort to communicate our approach internally. Internal team members develop an understanding based on prevalent practices.
name: Core Costs-cc_communication_channels_01-1

label: We don’t use our official channels to communicate our approach on core cost support internally. Our approach is often communicated at the senior management and board level. There is no mechanism to gather feedback on our guidelines from internal teams.
name: Core Costs-cc_communication_channels_01-2

label: We don’t use our official channels to communicate our guidelines on core cost support internally. Most teams, including the board and senior management, are aware of the guidelines. We sometimes gather internal feedback on the guidelines with the intent to improve our grantmaking approach.
name: Core Costs-cc_communication_channels_01-3

label: We do not communicate our approach on core cost support to nonprofits or make this information publicly available.
name: Core Costs-cc_communication_channels_02-1

label: We don’t use our website or other official means to communicate our approach on core cost support to nonprofits or the wider sector. Information is shared with nonprofits and select sector stakeholders on a one-on-one basis when the opportunity arises. Our communication with nonprofits primarily follows a one-way approach, with no or limited effort to seek their feedback. When exceptions are made, the reason is not communicated to nonprofits.
name: Core Costs-cc_communication_channels_02-2

label: We use our website or official means to communicate our guidelines on core cost support to nonprofits and the wider sector. We maintain communication with nonprofits and continuously seek their feedback to strengthen our grantmaking approach.
name: Core Costs-cc_communication_channels_02-4

label: We do not have written guidelines but may extend short-term OD support to nonprofit partners in exceptional circumstances. There are individuals amongst the decision makers in our organisation who are in favour of extending OD support to nonprofit partners.
name: Organisational Development-od_guidelines-2

label: We have written guidelines that stipulate short-term OD support that can be provided to nonprofit partners. The decision makers in our organisation understand that context may dictate the OD needs of nonprofit partners and are amenable to customising this on a case-by-case basis.
name: Organisational Development-od_guidelines-3

label: We have written guidelines that allows dedicated, long-term OD support to nonprofit partners. Decision makers in our organisation understand the importance of and are committed to supporting longer-term investments in OD for nonprofit partners.
name: Organisational Development-od_guidelines-4

label: We do not have a formal allocation in our budget for OD. Our funding for OD typically remains less than 5%.
name: Organisational Development-od_budget_allocation-2

label: We e have a formal allocation in our budget for OD which typically remains less than 10%.
name: Organisational Development-od_budget_allocation-3

label: We have a formal allocation in our budget for OD that typically is more than 10%.
name: Organisational Development-od_budget_allocation-4

label:
We provide short-term OD grants linked to the programmatic grants on a case-by-case basis.
AND
We may provide non-financial OD support to nonprofit partners either directly or in partnership with experts/external stakeholders.
name: Organisational Development-od_approaches_adopted_01-2

label:
We provide dedicated OD funding to most of our nonprofit partners.
AND
We may provide non-financial OD support to nonprofit partners either directly or in partnership with experts/external stakeholders.
name: Organisational Development-od_approaches_adopted_01-3

label:
We provide dedicated OD funding to all nonprofit partners.
AND
We may provide non-financial OD support to nonprofit partners either directly or in partnership with experts/external stakeholders.
name: Organisational Development-od_approaches_adopted_01-4

label:
We fund our nonprofit parnters only on select, predertermined OD aspects, as prescribed by our guidelines.
We do not consult nonprofit partners to understand present and future OD needs during the proposal phase.
We do not support or advise nonprofits on articulating their OD needs.
name: Organisational Development-od_approaches_adopted_02-2

label: Whilst we prefer to fund select OD aspects, we occasionally provide flexibility to nonprofit partners to choose areas beyond those. We sometimes consult nonprofit partners during the proposal phase to gauge alignment on our preferred areas of OD support and nonprofit parnters’ OD needs. We do not support or advise nonprofits on articulating their OD needs.
name: Organisational Development-od_approaches_adopted_02-3

label:
We fund OD areas based on nonprofit partners’ needs and context.
We – ourselves or through support from external partners – help nonprofit partners build a holistic OD plan.
The focus is on building a trusted relationship with our nonprofit partners.
name: Organisational Development-od_approaches_adopted_02-4

label:
We don’t use our official channels to communicate our approach on OD support internally. Our approach is often communicated at the senior management and board level.
There is no mechanism to gather feedback on our guidelines from internal teams.
name: Organisational Development-od_communication_channels_01-2

label:
We don’t use our official channels to communicate our guidelines on OD support internally. Most teams, including the board and senior management, are aware of the guidelines.
We sometimes gather internal feedback on the guidelines with the intent to improve our grantmaking approach.
name: Organisational Development-od_communication_channels_01-3

label:
We communicate our approach on OD support across the organisation using official means. All our teams have a clear understanding of the guidelines. This is documented and available to access internally.
We regularly gather internal feedback on the guidelines to improve our grantmaking approach.
name: Organisational Development-od_communication_channels_01-4

label:
We don’t use our website or other official channels to communicate our approach on OD support to nonprofits 
or the wider sector. Information is shared with nonprofits and select sector stakeholders on a one-on-one basis when the opportunity arises. Our communication with nonprofits primarily follows a one-way approach, with no or limited effort to seek their feedback. When exceptions are made, the reason is not communicated to nonprofits.
name: Organisational Development-od_communication_channels_02-2

label:
We use our website or other official channels to communicate our guidelines on OD support to nonprofits and the wider sector.
Information is shared with nonprofits before and during the proposal process. We sometimes share this information with the sector via formal communication channels as well.
We maintain communication with nonprofits, occasionally considering their feedback when deemed relevant or necessary.
name: Organisational Development-od_communication_channels_02-3

label:
We use our website or official means to communicate our guidelines on OD support to nonprofits and the wider sector.
We maintain communication with nonprofits and continuously seek their feedback to strengthen our grantmaking approach.
name: Organisational Development-od_communication_channels_02-4

label: We do not provide funding to strengthen the financial resilience of nonprofit partners.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_guidelines-1

label:
We do not have written guidelines to provide funding to strengthen the financial resilience of nonprofit partners.
We may provide non- financial support (e.g. helping them diversify their funder base, supporting financial planning, etc.) for building resilience on a one-off basis to nonprofit partners.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_guidelines-2

label: We have written guidelines that permits us to provide funding to strengthen the financial resilience of nonprofit partners. We may provide funding support and non-financial support (e.g. helping them diversify their funder base, supporting with financial planning, etc.) if requested by nonprofit partners. We have clear criteria for evaluating such requests.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_guidelines-3

label:
We have the ability to either make introductions to other funders to help the nonprofit partner increase the number of key funder relationships.
OR
We support nonprofit partners with their financial planning.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_approaches_adopted_01-2

label:
We have the ability to both make introductions to other funders to help the nonprofit partner increase the number of key funder relationships.
AND
We support nonprofit partners with their financial planning.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_approaches_adopted_01-3

label: We support nonprofit partners with their financial planning by leveraging internal or external experts. We make an effort to build a strong network of diverse funders. This allows us to work with nonprofits to identify who might be the right funders to support them and make direct connections.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_approaches_adopted_01-4

label: We allow nonprofit partners to transfer a share of operating surplus to reserves, in adherence to relevant regulations.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_approaches_adopted_02-2

label: We are comfortable with nonprofit partners creating an operating surplus and transferring all of the surplus to their reserves, in adherence to relevant regulations.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_approaches_adopted_02-3

label: We proactively provide dedicated grants or flexible funding to nonprofit partners which can be transferred to reserves, in adherence to relevant regulations.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_approaches_adopted_02-4

label: We don’t use our official channels to communicate our approach on financial resilience support internally. Our approach is often communicated at the senior management and board level. There is no mechanism to gather feedback on our guidelines from internal teams.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_communication_channels_01-2

label: We don’t use our official channels to communicate our guidelines on financial resilience support internally. Most teams, including the board and senior management, are aware of the guidelines. We sometimes gather internal feedback on the guidelines with the intent to improve our grantmaking approach.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_communication_channels_01-3

label: We communicate our approach on financial resilience support across the organisation using our website and other official means. All our teams have a clear understanding of the guidelines. This is documented and available internally. We regularly gather internal feedback on the guidelines to improve our grantmaking approach.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_communication_channels_01-4

label:
We don’t use our website or other official means to communicate our approach on financial resilience support to nonprofits or the wider sector.
Information is shared with nonprofits and select sector stakeholders on a one-on-one basis when the opportunity arises. Our communication with nonprofits primarily follows a one-way approach, with no or limited effort to seek their feedback.
When exceptions are made, the reason is not communicated to nonprofits.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_communication_channels_02-2

label:
We use our website or other official means to communicate our guidelines on financial resilience support to nonprofits and the wider sector. 
Information is shared with nonprofits before and during the proposal process. 
We sometimes share this information with the sector via formal communication channels as well. 
We maintain communication with nonprofits, occasionally considering their feedback when deemed relevant or necessary.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_communication_channels_02-3

label:
We use our website or official means to communicate our guidelines on financial resilience support to nonprofits and the wider sector. 
We maintain communication with nonprofits and continuously seek their feedback to strengthen our grantmaking approach.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_communication_channels_02-4

label: We do not have written guidelines on multiyear partnerships, but there is a shared understanding of how we should approach such partnerships. There are individual(s) amongst the decision makers who informally champion this approach.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_guidelines-2

label: We have written guidelines that provides high-level guidance on multiyear partnerships. Many people in senior leadership positions act as guardians of the approach.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_guidelines-3

label: We have written guidelines with clearly defined criteria that allows for uniform and consistent decision making on multiyear partnerships. There is collective guardianship and shared understanding of end goals of these guidelines.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_guidelines-4

label: We allocate 20–40% of our annual budget to multiyear partnerships.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_budget_allocation-3

label: We allocate 41–60% of our annual budget to multiyear partnerships.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_budget_allocation-2

label: We allocate 61% or more of our annual budget to multiyear partnerships.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_budget_allocation-4

label: We take a multiyear approach to partnerships but agreements need to be renewed on a yearly basis, aligned with our annual goals or compliance targets.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_01-2

label:
We do not have well-defined criteria.
We have formed multiyear partnerships with select nonprofit that have demonstrated a track record of delivering results on an annual basis.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_02-2

label: We have clear partner selection criteria. We enter into multiyear partnerships with select nonprofit partners with which we have cultivated a long-term relationship and are actively looking and planning to extend this to other nonprofit partners.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_02-3

label: We have clear partner selection criteria. We always enter into multiyear partnerships with our nonprofit partners.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_02-4

label: Our partners need to demonstrate proof of results every year to continue the partnership.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_03-2

label: We are somewhat flexible with our nonprofit partners’ actual results against the annual commitment as we understand the complexity of development initiatives.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_03-3

label: We don’t use our official channels to communicate our approach to multiyear partnerships internally. Our approach is often communicated at the senior management and board level. There is no mechanism to gather feedback on our guidelines from internal teams.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_communication_channels_01-2

label: We don’t use our official channels to communicate our guidelines on multiyear partnerships internally. Most teams, including the board and senior management, are aware of the guidelines. We sometimes gather internal feedback on the guidelines with the intent to improve our grantmaking approach.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_communication_channels_01-3

label: We don’t use our website or other official means to communicate our approach to multiyear partnerships to nonprofits or the wider sector. Information is shared with nonprofits and select sector stakeholders on a one-on-one basis when the opportunity arises. Our communication with nonprofits primarily follows a one-way approach, with no / limited effort to seek their feedback. When exceptions are made, the reason is not communicated to nonprofits.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_communication_channels_02-2

label: We use our website or other official means to communicate our guidelines on multiyear partnerships to nonprofits and the wider sector. Information is shared with nonprofits before and during the proposal process. We sometimes share this information with the sector via formal communication channels as well. We maintain communication with nonprofits, occasionally considering their feedback when deemed relevant or necessary.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_communication_channels_02-3

label: We use our website or official means to communicate our guidelines on multiyear partnerships to nonprofits and the wider sector. We maintain communication with nonprofits and continuously seek their feedback to strengthen our grantmaking approach.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_communication_channels_02-4

label: We communicate our approach on multiyear partnerships across the organisation using official means. All our teams have a clear understanding of the guidelines. This is documented and available internally. We regularly gather internal feedback on the guidelines to improve our grantmaking approach.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_communication_channels_01-4

label: We are flexible with the nonprofit partners’ actual results against the annual commitments as we understand the complexity of development initiatives.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_03-4

label: We always enter into partnerships with nonprofits through formal multiyear agreements.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_01-4

desc: The Foreign Contribution Regulation Act (FCRA) limits the amount of foreign funding nonprofits can spend on “administrative” or (non-programme) core costs to 20 percent.
label: We have written guidelines which stipulate an upper limit on the share of a grant that can be allocated towards core costs. However, our guidelines allow for flexibility based on the nonprofit partners’ context and need, whilst adhering to relevant regulations. The decision makers in our organisation understand that context may dictate the core cost need of the partner. They are amenable to customising cost coverage on a case-by-case basis.
name: Core Costs-cc_guidelines-3

label: We ask nonprofit partners to identify the disadvantaged community that they intend to serve.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_strategic_considerations_01-1

label: We believe that if the programmes are made available to a community, every constituent has equal opportunity to benefit from them, hence we do not actively nudge our grantee partners to clearly identify marginalised populations.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_strategic_considerations_01-2

label: We gather information either through data on outcomes related to our DEI focus (e.g. tracking the number of women or Adivasi participants achieving the desired outcomes) or through conversations with grantees and community members (e.g. field visits or stories of impact shared by grantees).
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_strategic_considerations_02-1

label: We do not seek such information from our grantees.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_strategic_considerations_02-2

label: We have an open call for applications that states eligibility criteria and the number of organisations to be selected.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_sourcing-1

label: We publicise grant application information in multiple languages in newspapers and/or other communication channels.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_sourcing-2

label: We seek referrals from existing grantees, alums, intermediary organisations, and other networks, especially those proximate to the communities we serve.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_sourcing-3

label: We make grant-related information (tenure, funding, conditions, etc.) available in multiple languages, including the languages that are spoken by the constituents that we want to serve.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_sourcing-4

label: We do not take any of these steps.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_sourcing-6

label: Our process allows for receiving applications in more than one language.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_application-1

label: We do not have a fixed, mandatory application format, and nonprofits can apply in a variety of ways, such as sharing their preexisting formats/documents, interviews, and video applications.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_application-2

label: We provide application support, such as webinars, one-on-one calls, help with filling out forms, and follow-ups for any missing information to applicants that otherwise would typically drop out of the process.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_application-3

label: We seek feedback from applicants and refine the application process to improve access and ease of application.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_application-4

label: We do not take any of the above steps.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_application-5

label: We ensure that the evaluation process takes into consideration the unique challenges that more proximate or community-led organisations may face, especially those that are new and have smaller budgets or teams.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_selection-1

label: We try to remove any exclusionary criteria, such as expectations for staff size, annual budget, or referrals from other funders.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_selection-2

label: We ensure that our grant officers/selection committee have a clear understanding of DEI considerations and take steps to mitigate any unconscious bias.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_selection-3

label: We seek feedback from our grantees to refine the selection criteria, prioritising essential aspects, addressing biases, and minimising unnecessary workload for future applicants.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_selection-4

label: We assess the demographic representation of applicant organisations at different stages of the process, including initial screening and final decisions, and steps in between.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_selection-5

label: We try to streamline diligence processes to minimise the time and effort required to complete a grant application.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_diligence-1

label: We acknowledge the power differential between funders and nonprofits by engaging in dialogue with a learning orientation, recognising the experience and expertise of nonprofits in the field, and striving to built trust with grantees.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_diligence-2

label: We fund stipends to organisations, especially smaller or more proximate ones, that reach the advanced stage of diligence, recognising the costs they incur and resources they commit by participating in the process.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_diligence-3

label: We are open to field visits and conversations with prospective grantees to learn more about a nonprofit’s needs and experiences instead of solely relying on documentation.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_diligence-4

label: We do not take any of the above steps.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_diligence-5

label: We evaluate the importance and relevance of the information we seek on a periodic basis to simplify the application process.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grant_setup_and_disbursement-1

label: We minimise the information-sharing burden for grantees during the grant award process by seeking only critical information, either in writing or through an interview.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grant_setup_and_disbursement-2

label: Our grant disbursement schedule takes into consideration the unique context of each grantee, including allowing them to seek larger disbursements in the beginning of the programme.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grant_setup_and_disbursement-3

label: We collate preexisting sources of information (including prior application[s] or public databases), which grantee partners can then validate or update.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grant_setup_and_disbursement-4

label: We help grantees integrate DEI considerations into their programmes by providing appropriate organisational development (OD) training.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grantee_support-1

label: We regularly engage in DEI dialogues with grantees, bring in experts to provide advice, and/or support peer learning amongst our grantees.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grantee_support-2

label: We do not take any of the above steps.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grantee_support-3

label: All our grant officers, programme managers, and staff members are trained to mitigate unconscious bias to ensure respectful relationships with all grantees.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grantee_engagement-1

label: We have multiple channels for our grantees to provide formal or informal feedback, including anonymously, on the effectiveness of our grants and processes.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grantee_engagement-2

label: We strive to deepen internal understanding of the grantees’ community contexts and ground realities by attending community and grantee events whilst thoughtfully navigating power dynamics.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grantee_engagement-3

label: We periodically share updates with our grantees, including internal and portfolio progress, learnings and success stories, and our future direction.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grantee_engagement-4

label: We do not take any of the above steps.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grantee_engagement-5

label: Our monitoring, learning, and evaluation (MLE) process is designed to facilitate learning both for us and our grantees.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_reporting-1

label: We minimise the reporting burden by allowing grantees to provide information in the formats available to them or through conversations and interviews.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_reporting-2

label: We periodically review our reporting requirements with an objective to collect only useful information and avoid collection of data without any explicit purpose.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_reporting-3

label: We do not take any of the above steps.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_reporting-4

label: The ability of grantees to serve marginalised communities enhances their prospects for grant renewal.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_renewal-1

label: We do not specifically track DEI indicators as long as the overall grant objectives are being met.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_renewal-2

label: We do not take any of the above steps.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_selection-6

label: We do not take any of the above steps.
name: Diversity Equity Inclusion-dei_grant_setup_and_disbursement-5

label: We do not have documented guidelines. There is a difference of opinion amongst decision-makers on how much core-cost support we should be extending to nonprofit partners.
name: Core Costs-cc_guidelines-1

desc: The Foreign Contribution Regulation Act (FCRA) limits the amount of foreign funding nonprofits can spend on “administrative” or (non-programme) core costs to 20 percent.
label: We do not have a fixed core cost range and provide support as per the ask, need, and cost structures of the nonprofit partner, whilst adhering to relevant regulations. We actively engage with and consult nonprofit partners during the proposal phase to better understand their cost structures and needs.
name: Core Costs-cc_approaches_adopted_01-4

label: There is room for negotiation for all nonprofit partners. We are able to vary the core cost range by 2% to 5% based on the needs of the nonprofit partner whilst supporting and advising them on how best to optimise the pool of core cost support available.
name: Core Costs-cc_approaches_adopted_02-3

label: We communicate our approach on core cost support across the organisation using official means. All our teams have a clear understanding of the guidelines. This is documented and available internally. We regularly gather internal feedback on the guidelines to improve our grantmaking approach.
name: Core Costs-cc_communication_channels_01-4

label: We use our website or other official means to communicate our guidelines on core cost support to nonprofits and the wider sector. Information is shared with nonprofits before and during the proposal process. We sometimes share this information with the sector via formal communication channels as well. We maintain communication with nonprofits, occasionally considering their feedback when deemed relevant or necessary.
name: Core Costs-cc_communication_channels_02-3

label: We do not have written guidelines. There is a difference of opinion amongst decision makers on this aspect.
name: Organisational Development-od_guidelines-1

label: We do not allocate any budget for OD in our annual grants.
name: Organisational Development-od_budget_allocation-1

label:
We do not provide any OD grants to nonprofit partners.
OR
We only provide some short-duration training support to nonprofit partners.
name: Organisational Development-od_approaches_adopted_01-1

label: We do not provide any OD grants to our nonprofit partners.
name: Organisational Development-od_approaches_adopted_02-1

label: We do not make an effort to communicate our approach internally. Internal team members develop an understanding based on prevalent practices.
name: Organisational Development-od_communication_channels_01-1

label: We do not communicate our approach on OD support to nonprofits or make this information publicly available.
name: Organisational Development-od_communication_channels_02-1

label: We have written guidelines that mandate we provide funding to strengthen the financial resilience of nonprofit partners. Our guidelines provide direction on non-financial support (e.g. helping nonprofits diversify their funder base, supporting financial planning, etc.) that we can extend to nonprofit partners, if requested. There is a shared understanding within the organisation of the importance of extending support for financial resilience.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_guidelines-4

label: We do not help nonprofit partners build their resilience through non-financial support.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_approaches_adopted_01-1

label: We do not provide financial support to nonprofit partners for building their reserves.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_approaches_adopted_02-1

label: We do not make an effort to communicate our approach internally. Internal team members develop an understanding based on prevalent practices.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_communication_channels_01-1

label: We do not communicate our approach on financial resilience support to nonprofits or make this information publicly available.
name: Financial Resilience-fr_communication_channels_02-1

label: We do not have written guidelines. Multiyear partnerships are not a consideration of decision makers in our organisation. There is a difference of opinion amongst decision makers on this aspect.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_guidelines-1

label: We provide less than 20% of our annual budget to multiyear grants.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_budget_allocation-1

label: We approach grants with an annual horizon which may lead to a nonprofit receiving support over multiple years.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_01-1

label:
We do not seek to enter into
multiyear partnerships with our nonprofit partners.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_02-1

label: We do not enter into multiyear partnerships with nonprofit partners.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_approaches_adopted_03-1

label: We do not make an effort to communicate our approach internally. Internal team members develop an understanding based on prevalent practices.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_communication_channels_01-1

label: We do not communicate our guidelines for multiyear partnerships to nonprofits or make this information publicly available.
name: Multi-year Partnerships-myp_communication_channels_02-1
